I bow to the nature of consciousness-only, the perfected and complete purifiers.
I will now explain what they have said, for the benefit and joy of all beings.
The present treatise is composed in order to generate correct understanding for those who are confused or mistaken about the two kinds of emptiness.

Understanding is generated in order to sever the two kinds of heavy obstructions, because when the two kinds of grasping at self and dharmas are present, the two obstructions arise together. If one realizes the two kinds of emptiness, those obstructions will be severed accordingly.

Severing the obstructions is for the sake of attaining the two supreme fruits. By severing the afflictive obstructions that perpetuate birth and death, one realizes true liberation. By severing the obstructions to the knowable that hinder understanding, one attains great enlightenment.

Moreover, it is in order to reveal and instruct those who mistakenly grasp at self and dharmas and are confused about consciousness-only, causing them to penetrate the two kinds of emptiness and correctly understand the principle of consciousness-only.

There are also those who are confused about the principle of consciousness only, who either grasp external objects as not nonexistent like consciousness, or grasp internal consciousness as not existent like objects, or grasp the various consciousnesses as having different functions but the same substance, or grasp that apart from mind there are no separate mental factors. In order to refute these various heterodox views and enable one to attain correct understanding of the profound principle of consciousness only, this treatise is composed.
If there is only consciousness, how do the world and the holy teachings speak of the existence of self and dharmas?
The verse says:
There are various aspects of transformation,
They are based on the transformation of consciousness. This transforming [consciousness] is only three:
The store consciousness, manas, and the six consciousnesses, which perceive objects.
The treatise says:
The world and the holy teachings speak of the existence of self and dharmas, but this is only a provisional designation, not their real nature.
Self refers to the master and controller, and dharmas refer to the guiding principles and upheld phenomena. Both of them have various aspects of transformation.
The various aspects of self refer to sentient beings, living beings, etc., and stream-enterers, once-returners, etc.
The various characteristics of dharmas are such things as reality, virtue, action, etc., and such things as aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields.
Transformation means that there are differences in designation in accordance with conditions.
If these characteristics are due to provisional designation, on what basis are they established?
These characteristics are all provisionally established on the basis of the transformation of consciousness.
Consciousness means discrimination. The word consciousness here also includes mental activities, because they are definitely associated.
Transformation means that the substance of consciousness transforms into the appearance of two parts, because the seen and seeing parts both arise on the basis of self-awareness.
On the basis of these two parts, self and dharmas are provisionally established, because apart from them, they have no basis.

Or, internal consciousness transforms into the appearance of external objects, because of the power of perfuming of discrimination of self and dharmas. When consciousnesses arise, they transform into the appearance of self and dharmas. Although the characteristics of self and dharmas are in internal consciousness, they appear as if external objects because of discrimination.

Since beginningless time, sentient beings have taken this as a real self and real dharmas. It is like a person who is ill and dreaming. Because of the power of the illness, the mind manifests images of various external objects, and on the basis of this, one grasps at real external objects.
The real selves and real dharmas imagined by the ignorant do not exist at all, but are established in accordance with false ideas. Therefore, they are said to be fictional.

The transformations of internal consciousness that resemble a self and dharmas exist, but they are not of the nature of real selves and dharmas. However, they are said to be fictional because they appear to be those real selves and dharmas.
External objects are established in accordance with ideas and therefore do not exist as do consciousnesses.
Internal consciousnesses necessarily arise in dependence on causes and conditions and therefore are not nonexistent, like objects. This refutes the two extreme views of increase and decrease.
Objects are provisionally established in dependence on internal consciousnesses and therefore exist only conventionally.
Consciousness is the support for fictional objects and therefore exists ultimately.
How do we know that external objects do not really exist and that internal consciousness arises resembling external objects?
Because real selves and real dharmas cannot be found.
How can a real self not be apprehended?
The selves that are grasped are, in brief, of three kinds:
The first is the view that the substance of the self is permanent, all-pervading, and as immense as space, because it creates karma in various places and experiences suffering and happiness.
The second is the view that the substance of the self is permanent but its size is indefinite, because it contracts and expands according to the size of the body.
The third is the view that the substance of the self is permanent but extremely subtle, like a single atom, and it moves about secretly in the body and performs actions.
The first is not reasonable.
Why is this?
If the self is grasped as permanent, all-pervading, and as immense as space, it should not experience suffering and happiness according to the body.
Moreover, because it is permanent and all-pervading, it should not move. How can it follow the body and create various actions?
Moreover, is the self grasped as the same for all sentient beings or different?

If it is said to be the same, then when one creates karma, all should create it, and when one experiences the results, all should experience them. When one attains liberation, all should attain it. This would be a great error.
If you say that the self is different from the body, then the self of all sentient beings would be mutually pervasive and therefore their bodies would be mixed up.

Also, when one performs an action and experiences a result, since there is no difference in location from all other selves, it should be said that all selves perform and experience the action and result.

If you say that there is no error because the action and the experiencer are related to a particular self, this is also unreasonable, because the action, the result, and the body are related to the various selves, and it is unreasonable to say that they belong to this one and not to that one.
When one is liberated, all should be liberated, because the Dharma that is cultivated and realized is related to all selves.
The middle view is also unreasonable.
Why is this?
The substance of the self is eternally abiding and should not expand and contract along with the body.
Since it expands and contracts, like the wind in a bellows, it should not be eternally abiding.
Also, since the self follows the body, it should be divisible. How can you hold that the substance of the self is one?
Therefore, what they say is like a child playing with building blocks.
The last view is also unreasonable.
Why is this?
How can it cause the entire body to move if it is as small as an atom?

If you say that although it is small, it quickly moves through the body like a whirling torch, causing the body to move, then the self that you posit is not unitary and permanent, because it moves from place to place, and that which moves is not unitary and permanent.
Also, the self that is posited is of three kinds:
the first is identical to the aggregates, the second is separate from the aggregates, and the third is neither identical to the aggregates nor separate from them.
The first, the self that is identical to the aggregates, is not reasonable, because the self would be impermanent and not unitary, like the aggregates.
Also, the internal material elements are definitely not the real self, because they are material and obstructive, like external material elements.
Mental activities and mental factors are also not the real self, because they are not a continuous series and depend on many conditions.
The remaining activities and the remaining material elements are also not the real self, because they are like space and so on and do not have the nature of awareness.
The middle position, the self that is separate from the aggregates, is also unreasonable, because it would be like space and would not have the function of knowing and feeling.

The latter two alternatives are also unreasonable, because it is admitted that the self is established on the basis of the aggregates, but is neither identical with nor different from the aggregates. It should be like a pot, etc., and not a real self.
Moreover, since it cannot be said that the self is conditioned or unconditioned, it also cannot be said that the self is or is not a self. Therefore the real self that is grasped does not exist.
Moreover, as for the substance of the self that is grasped as really existing, does it have thought or does it not have thought?
If it has thought, it should be impermanent, because it is not always associated with thought.
If it does not have thought, it should be like empty space, unable to act or experience results.
Therefore the self that is grasped does not exist in either case.
Moreover, as for the substance of the self that is grasped as really existing, does it have activity or does it not have activity?
If it has activity, it should be impermanent, like hands and feet, etc.
If it does not have activity, like the horns of a rabbit, etc., it should not be a real self.
Therefore the self that is grasped does not exist in either case.
Also, is the substance of the self that you affirm as really existing the object-support of the view of a self?
If it is not the object-support of the view of a self, how do you know that a self really exists?
If it is the object-support of the view of a self, then the view of a self must not be included among the inverted views, because it is in accordance with reality.

If this is so, how is it that the scriptures that you accept as authoritative all condemn the view of a self and praise the view of no-self, saying that the view of no-self can realize nirvÄá¹‡a, while the view of a self is submerged in saá¹ƒsÄra?
Can a false view realize nirvÄá¹‡a, while a correct view causes one to be submerged in saá¹ƒsÄra?
Also, the various views of a self do not have as their object a real self, because they have an object, just as in the case of other minds.
The object-support of the view of a self is definitely not a real self, because it is an object-support, just as in the case of other dharmas.

Therefore the view of a self does not have as its object a real self. It only has as its object the various aggregates that are transformations of internal consciousness, which are imagined in various ways in accordance with oneâ€™s own deluded feelings.
There are, however, two kinds of self-attachment:
one is innate and the other is resulting from discrimination.

The innate self-attachment has been perfumed since beginningless time by the power of internal causes and is always associated with the body. It does not depend on false teachings or discrimination and evolves spontaneously, and for that reason it is called innate.
This attachment is of two kinds:
one is always in a series and is in the seventh consciousness, where it takes as its object the eighth consciousness and generates the image of its own mind, which it grasps as a real self.

The second kind is interrupted and is in the sixth consciousness, where it takes as its object the images of the five aggregates that are transformed by consciousness, either in general or in particular, and generates the image of its own mind, which it grasps as a real self.

These two kinds of self-attachment are subtle and therefore difficult to eliminate. They are removed only by repeated cultivation of the superior contemplation of the emptiness of beings during the path of cultivation.

Self-attachment resulting from discrimination is not associated with the body, because it results from the power of external conditions in the present moment. It does not appear until after false teachings and discrimination. For that reason it is called discrimination, and it exists only in the sixth consciousness.
These two kinds of clinging are also of two kinds.

The first is that which arises on the basis of the characteristics of the aggregates as taught in false doctrines, and the second is that which arises on the basis of the characteristics of self as taught in false doctrines.
These two kinds of clinging to a self are gross and therefore easy to eliminate.
When one first sees the path, one contemplates the true suchness of the emptiness of beings in all dharmas and is able to eliminate them.

All the above mentioned clinging to a self may or may not exist externally in relation to mind, but all exist internally in relation to mind. Therefore, all clinging to a self is the false grasping of a self on the basis of the characteristics of the five aggregates that are grasped, which are impermanent.
However, the characteristics of the aggregates are like illusions, because they are produced from conditions. The self that is grasped by delusion is imagined and therefore definitely does not exist.
Therefore a scripture says,
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that all views of a self of the Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as of the world arise on the basis of the five aggregates that are grasped.

If there is no real self, how can there be memory, recognition, recitation, learning, gratitude, resentment, and so forth?ğŸ”½If the real self that is grasped is permanent and unchanging, then later it should be as it was before, and before it should be as it is later, because the later is not different from the earlier.

If you say that the activity of the self changes before and after, but the substance of the self does not, this is also unreasonable, because the activity is not separate from the substance, it should always exist; and the substance is not separate from the activity, it should not be permanent.

However, all sentient beings each have a fundamental consciousness that continues in a single series, holding the seeds, and mutually serve as causes for all dharmas. Due to the power of perfuming, there can be such things as memory, recognition, and so forth.
Therefore, the difficulty you set up is a fault in your own position, not in our school.ğŸ”½If there is no real self, who can create karma and who experiences the results?
If the real self that is grasped is without change, like empty space, how can it possibly create karma and experience its results?
If it undergoes transformation, it must be impermanent.
However, the mind and mental factors of sentient beings, by the power of causes and conditions, continue without interruption, creating karma and experiencing its results, which is reasonable.
If the self does not really exist, who is it that transmigrates through the various destinies in the cycle of birth and death?
And who is it that tires of suffering and seeks to enter nirvana?
Since the real self that is grasped does not arise or cease, how can it be said that it transmigrates through the cycle of birth and death?
Always like empty space, not troubled by suffering, why would it tire of and abandon it to seek to enter nirvana?
Therefore, what they say is always self-defeating.

However, the mental and physical continua of sentient beings, by the power of afflictions and karma, transmigrate through the various destinies, and because they tire of suffering, they seek to enter nirvana.
For this reason, we know that there definitely is no real self.

There are only various consciousnesses, which arise and cease in sequence from beginningless time, and the causes and effects continue. Due to false perfuming, the appearance of a self arises. Fools falsely grasp it as a self.
How can it be known that external real dharmas do not exist?
Because the external dharmas grasped by non-Buddhists and other vehicles are not real.
Why are the external dharmas grasped by non-Buddhists not real?
First, the SÄá¹ƒkhya school holds that the self is thought that experiences the three qualities of sattva, rajas, and tamas, and is composed of the twenty-three dharmas beginning with mahat.
However, the dharmas beginning with mahat are composed of three things, are real, not provisional, and are grasped by perception.
Their view is unreasonable.
Why is this?
Because the dharmas beginning with mahat are composed of many things, like an army or a forest, they should be provisional, not real. How can it be said that they are grasped by perception?
Moreover, if the dharmas beginning with mahat really exist, they should be like the original nature, not composed of three things.
Because the three qualities of sattva, etc., are the same as mahat, etc., they should also be composed of three things.
The same is true for the example of transformation and impermanence.
Moreover, the three original natures each have many functions, and their substance should also be many.
Because their substance is one, when one changes, the other two must also change, because their substance is not different.
If you admit that the three substances are different from each other in their characteristics, how can they combine to form a single characteristic?
They cannot change into a single characteristic when they combine, because their substance is not different from what it was before they combined.
If you say that the three substances are different but their characteristics are the same, then you contradict your own doctrine that substance and characteristic are one.
Substance should be like characteristic and be completely one, and characteristic should be like substance and be clearly three. Therefore you cannot say that the three combine to form one.
Moreover, three is a particular number, and one, great, etc., are general terms. Because the particular and the general are one, there should not be one three.
When the three change, if they do not combine to form a single characteristic, they should be like they were before they changed. How is it that we now see them as one color, etc.?
If the three combine to form a single characteristic, they should lose their original particular characteristics, and their substance should also be lost.
You cannot say that the three each have two characteristics, one general and one particular.
Because the general is identical with the particular, the general should also be three. How can you see it as one?
If you say that each of the three natures has three characteristics, and they are mixed together and difficult to know, so they are seen as one,
since there are three characteristics, how can they be seen as one?
Moreover, how do you know that the three things are different?
If each of them has three characteristics, each thing should be able to form color, etc. What is lacking that it needs the combination of the three?
The natures should also be three, because the nature is identical with the characteristics.

Moreover, the dharmas such as the great elements are all formed by the combination of three. They should be no different from each other in mutual comparison. In that case, the cause and effect, the various great elements, and the differences of the various faculties would all not be established.
If so, one faculty should be able to obtain all objects, or one object should be obtained by all faculties.
The present and past seen in the world, sentient beings and insentient beings, pure and defiled things, direct perception, inference, etc., should all be no different, which would be a great mistake.
Therefore the real dharmas that they posit do not exist, and they are only imagined to exist by deluded feelings.
The SÄá¹ƒkhyas say that many of the categories such as pradhÄna really exist and are perceived by perception.
This doctrine is unreasonable.
Why?
If the permanent generates effects, it must be impermanent, because it has activity, like the generated effects.
If it does not generate effects, it must not have a nature apart from consciousness that really exists, like the horns of a rabbit.
If the impermanent has spatial dimensions, it must be divisible, like an army or a forest, and it does not have a real nature.
If it is without spatial dimensions, like mind and mental activities, it must not have a real nature apart from these.
Also, the earth, water, fire, and wind that they posit must not be obstructed, because they are categorized as real things and are contacted by the body faculty.

If solidity, fluidity, heat, and motion are the natures of earth, water, fire, and wind, then solidity, fluidity, heat, and motion must not be included in the category of qualities that are unimpeded, because they are touched by the body faculty, just as earth, water, fire, and wind are.
Earth, water, and fire, when opposed to the color blue, etc., are all seen by the eye.

This should be used to criticize the VaibhÄá¹£ika position. Therefore we know that there is no real earth, water, fire, and wind that have a separate nature of solidity, fluidity, etc., and that the eye does not see real earth, water, and fire.
Also, the real categories that the VaibhÄá¹£ikas posit as impeded and permanent must all be impeded, like gross earth, etc., and therefore must be impermanent.

Among the various categories, dharmas that are grasped by the sense faculties and are not impeded must all be impeded, because they are grasped by the sense faculties, just as earth, water, fire, and wind are.ğŸ”½Also, the non-real qualities, etc. that they posit must not have a separate nature apart from consciousness, because they are not included in the real, just like the son of a barren woman.
The non-existent real, etc. must not have a separate nature apart from consciousness, because they are not included in the existent, just like space flowers, etc.
The nature of existence that they grasp must be devoid of a self-nature apart from substance, etc., because it is admitted that it is not nonexistent, just as substance, quality, etc. are.
If it is devoid of substance, etc., it must not be the nature of existence, because it is admitted that it is different from substance, etc., just as absolute nonexistence, etc. are.
Just as existence is not nonexistent, and there is no nature of existence apart from it, how can substance, etc. have a nature of existence apart from them?
If the nature of existence is different from the existent dharma, there must be a nature of nonexistence apart from the nonexistent.
Since that is not so, how can this be so?

Therefore the nature of existence is only falsely imagined.ğŸ”½Moreover, the nature of substance, quality, and action that they grasp must not be different from substance, quality, and action, because it is admitted that they are not nonexistent, just as substance, etc. are.
It must not be that substance, etc. are not categorized as substance, etc., because they are different from substance, etc., just as quality, action, etc. are.
The natures of earth, etc. should be understood in the same way as substance, etc. when they are questioned about their identity or difference.
The nature of reality and so forth have no separate real natures and so forth, and real and so forth should also have no separate natures and so forth.
If the nature of reality and so forth exists apart from reality and so forth, then the nature of unreality and so forth should exist apart from nonreality and so forth.
Since that is not so, how could this be so?
Therefore the natures of sameness and difference are only nominally established.

Moreover, the meaning of the category of combination definitely does not really exist, because it is not included among such real dharmas as existence and so forth, just as absolute nonexistence is not.

They admit that existence and so forth are perceived by direct perception, but even when they are investigated by reason, they still do not really exist, much less do they admit that the meaning of the category of combination, not being perceived by direct perception, really exists.
Even if one grasps the object of combination as the object of direct perception, it still does not really exist, because of the previous reasoning.

However, existence and so forth are not perceived by direct perception as having a self-nature apart from consciousness and existing separately, because they are admitted to be knowable, just as the hair of a tortoise and so forth are.

Moreover, the knowledge that has real things as objects is not knowledge that has as its object the substance of the category of real things apart from consciousness, because it is included in knowledge that is born of a combination of causes, like the knowledge of qualities, etc.

This is extended to the knowledge that has combinations as objects, which is not knowledge that has as its object the substance of the combination apart from consciousness, because it is included in knowledge that is born of a combination of causes, like the knowledge of real things, etc.
Consequently, the categories of real things, etc., of the VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas are also falsely established according to their whims.
There is an opinion that there is a single great ÄªÅ›vara, whose substance is real, who is all-pervading and eternal, and who is able to generate all things.
This opinion is unreasonable.
Why is it unreasonable?
Because if a dharma is able to generate, it must not be eternal, because all that is not eternal must not be all-pervading, and because all that is not all-pervading must not be real.
If its substance is eternal and all-pervading and endowed with all potencies, then it must suddenly generate all things in all places and times.
If it is able to generate only after waiting for desire or conditions, then this contradicts the doctrine of a single cause.
Or, desire and conditions must also suddenly arise, because the cause is eternally existent.

The rest of the schools that hold that there is a permanent, real Great Brahma, time, space, the primal substance, nature, void, or self, which has all potencies and generates all dharmas, are refuted in the same way.ğŸ”½There is another school that holds that the sound of the Vedas is permanent and can serve as a means of knowing and expressing all dharmas.
There is another school that holds that all sounds are permanent and are only manifested by conditions and then express meaning.
Both of these are unreasonable.
Why is this?
First, the sound of the Vedas is said to be able to express meaning and therefore must not be permanent, like other sounds.
Other sounds also must not be permanent, because their substance, like pots and clothing, etc., must wait for many conditions.
There is a non-Buddhist school that holds that the most subtle particles of earth, water, fire, and wind are really permanent and can generate gross form.
The gross form that is generated does not exceed the dimensions of its causes. Although it is impermanent, its substance is really existent.
This is also unreasonable.
Why is this?
If the atoms you posit have parts, like a line of ants, then they cannot be real entities.
If they have no parts, like mind and mental activities, then they cannot combine to produce gross fruit-colors.
Since they can produce fruit, how can you say that atoms are permanent?

Also, since the size of the fruit is no greater than that of the cause, it should be like the atom and not be called gross color. In that case, the fruit-color should not be perceived by the eye and other material organs, which contradicts your own tenets.ğŸ”½You may say that the size and qualities of the fruit-color combine, so that it is not gross but seems to be, and the material organs can perceive it.
But since the size of the fruit-color is no greater than that of the cause, it should be like the atom and not have the qualities of grossness.
Or else, the atom should have the qualities of grossness, because it is not different from the gross fruit-color.

If you say that the fruit-color is in its own causes, and because the causes are not one, it is called gross, then the substance of the fruit-color should not be one, because it is in its causes, which are in different places.
In that case, the effect is not coarse, and therefore it is not perceived by the material organs.

If the effect is coarse because it is a combination of many parts, then many causes, which are combinations of atoms, should not be subtle, and they would be sufficient as objects of the organs. What need is there for an effect?
If they are formed by many parts, they should not be real, and your theory is self-contradictory.
Also, if the effect and the cause both have resistance, they should not occupy the same place, just as two atoms do not.
If you say that the effect and the cause interpenetrate each other, like sand holding water and medicine dissolving in molten bronze,
who would admit that sand and bronze hold water and medicine?
Either they would be separated or transformed, and not one and not permanent.
Also, if the substance of the coarse effect is one, then when one part is obtained, all should be obtained, because all are one.

If you do not admit this, you contradict reason. If you do admit it, you contradict experience. Therefore the theories of the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas are untenable whether examined in terms of reason or in terms of experience. They are mere arbitrary imaginings.
Although the various non-Buddhist schools are numerous, the dharmas they posit do not go beyond four kinds:
1. Some posit that the substance of dharmas is definitely the same as the nature of existence, like the SÄá¹ƒkhyas and others.
Their position is unreasonable.
Why is this?
Do not let all dharmas be the nature of existence,

so that they are all the same as the nature of existence, without any difference in substance. This would contradict the difference in substance between the three qualities and the self, and also contradict the various differences among worldly dharmas.
Moreover, if form, etc. were the nature of form, etc., form should not have differences such as blue, yellow, etc.
2. Some posit that the substance of dharmas is definitely different from the nature of existence, like the VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas and others.
Their position is unreasonable.
Why is this?
Do not let all dharmas not be the nature of existence,

like the non-existence that has already ceased, whose substance cannot be apprehended. This would contradict the non-non-existence of the substance of earth, etc., and also contradict the presently existent existence seen in the world.
Moreover, if form, etc. were not the nature of form, etc., it would be like sound, etc. not being the object of the eyes, etc.
Third, some hold that dharmas and existence, etc., are both the same and different, like shamelessness, etc.
Their thesis is unreasonable.
Why?

Because the errors of sameness and difference are the same as before, because the two natures of sameness and difference should be different, and because sameness and difference cannot both be established if they have the same nature.
Do not let all dharmas be the same in nature, or else sameness and difference should be conventional and not real, but to hold them to be real is definitely unreasonable.
Fourth, some hold that dharmas and existence, etc., are neither the same nor different, like wrong livelihood, etc.
Their thesis is unreasonable.
Why?
Because the thesis of neither sameness nor difference is the same as the thesis of sameness and difference.
Does the statement neither the same nor different negate or affirm?
If it only affirms, it should not be a double negation.
If it only negates, there should be no thesis.
If it both negates and affirms, it should contradict itself.
If it neither affirms nor negates, it should become empty talk.

Also, the assertion that form is neither the same as nor different from consciousness contradicts the common knowledge of the world that there are things that are either the same as or different from something else. It also contradicts the YogÄcÄrinâ€™s own doctrine that form and other dharmas are real.
Therefore, the above assertion is nothing but a vain attempt to avoid the error of nihilism. No wise person would accept it.
How do we know that the dharmas of form, etc., apart from consciousness, as grasped by other Buddhist schools, do not exist?
Because the form grasped by other schools, as well as the dharmas unassociated with mind and the various unconditioned dharmas, are unreasonable.
Form grasped by other schools is of two kinds:
that which is resistant and composed of atoms;
and that which is nonresistant and not composed of atoms.
Resistant form definitely does not really exist, because the atoms that compose it do not really exist.
If atoms have resistance, they must be like vases, etc., and be unreal.
If they have no resistance, they must be like mind, etc., and how can they be aggregated to form vases, clothing, etc.?
Also, if atoms have spatial dimensions, they must be divisible and therefore not real.
If it has no spatial dimensions, then it is like nonform. How can it combine to receive light and cast shadows?

When the sun has just risen and shines on a pillar, etc., light and shadow appear on both the east and west sides. Since the place where it receives light and casts shadows is different, the extremely subtle particles definitely have spatial dimensions.

Moreover, if when one sees or touches a wall, etc., one only obtains this side and does not obtain the other side, since the combined object is precisely the extremely subtle particles, these extremely subtle particles must have spatial dimensions.

Moreover, wherever the extremely subtle particles abide, they must have distinctions of above, below, the four directions. Otherwise, there would be no meaning of combining together, or they would interpenetrate and not form the coarse. For this reason, the extremely subtle particles definitely have spatial dimensions.
If one grasps the resistant form as precisely the extremely subtle particles, if they have no spatial dimensions, there should be no obstruction. If so, then they are not resistant as obstruction.

Therefore the atoms that you maintain must have parts, and because they have parts they can be analyzed and certainly do not really exist. Therefore the reality of resistant, or obstructive, form is not established.
Are the five consciousnesses not without form as a support and object?
Although they are not without form, they are transformations of consciousness.
That is, when consciousness is born, the power of internal causes and conditions transforms and manifests as images of eyes, etc., and form, etc. These images are the support and object.
However, the eyes, etc., are not perceived by perception, but we infer that they exist because they are able to generate consciousness. They are only functions and not external material objects.
Since external resistant form is not established by reason, it must be the transformation of internal consciousness.

That which generates the eye consciousness, etc., is called the eyes, etc. These are the supports that generate the eye consciousness, etc. Since the external objects that are the perceived objects of these eye consciousnesses, etc., do not exist, you must definitely admit that the objects of perception are the transformations of oneâ€™s own consciousness. That is, that which is able to generate something similar to consciousness is what you hold to be the condition as object of perception.
It is not only that it is able to produce consciousness, because the conditions such as the object are also the condition as object of this consciousness.
When the five consciousnesses such as visual consciousness perceive form, etc., they only have as objects the unities that resemble them.

The characteristics of unities are not different from the atoms that constitute them, because when the atoms are analyzed, the consciousness that has the characteristics of the unities definitely does not occur.
Since the characteristics of unities do not really exist, they cannot be said to be objects of the five consciousnesses, because the second moon, etc., cannot produce the five consciousnesses.
The atoms in a state of aggregation cannot be the objects of the five consciousnesses, because the characteristics of atoms are not present in consciousness.
The atoms do not have the characteristics of aggregation, because when they are not aggregated, they do not have these characteristics.

The atoms in a state of aggregation are not different from the atoms when they are not aggregated, and therefore, just as when they are not aggregated, the atoms of form, etc., are not objects of the five consciousnesses.

Some say that when atoms of form, etc., are not combined, they are not objects of the five forms of consciousness, but when combined, they mutually assist each other and a gross aspect is produced that becomes the object of these consciousnesses. This gross aspect really exists and is the object of these consciousnesses.
This interpretation is not correct, because when combined, the atoms are the same in substance and characteristics as when not combined.
If the atoms of a pot, a bowl, etc., are the objects, the consciousnesses of these objects should not be different.
If, when combined, each atom gives up its minute, round characteristics,

then a consciousness of a gross aspect cannot have as its object an object with a subtle aspect, because it would be like a consciousness of one object having another object as its object, and one consciousness would have all objects as its object.
If you admit the existence of atoms, you still commit these errors, not to mention the fact that there are no real atoms apart from consciousness.

Therefore, you must definitely admit that what is transformed by oneâ€™s own consciousness and resembles form, etc., is the condition as object of the five consciousnesses, because seeing is born in dependence on that and takes on its characteristics.

However, when consciousness transforms, it suddenly manifests a single image according to the size of the object, and it does not transform separately into many subtle atoms that combine to form a single thing.
For those who grasp at the reality of gross form, the Buddha speaks of subtle atoms in order to have them eliminate and analyze it. It is not that all forms really have subtle atoms.
YogÄcÄra masters use conceptual wisdom to gradually eliminate and analyze the images of gross form until they cannot be further analyzed. They provisionally speak of subtle atoms.

Although these subtle atoms still have spatial dimensions, they cannot be further analyzed. If one further analyzes them, they appear to be empty space and are not called form. Therefore, it is said that subtle atoms are the limit of form.
From this, one should understand that all resistant forms are manifestations of consciousness and are not composed of subtle atoms.
The remaining nonresistant forms are of the same kind and are also not real.
Or, because they are nonresistant, like mind and mental factors, they definitely are not real form.

All resisting forms are presently seen to have the characteristics of form. If one investigates them with reason, they do not exist apart from consciousness. How much less can formless dharmas, which are presently seen to have no characteristics of form, be said to be real form?
How can it be that the form of indication and nonindication is not really existent?
It is not really existent.
Why is this?
If bodily intimation is really existent, of what is it composed?
If it is said to be shape, it is not really existent, because it is divisible and because there is no atom of length, etc.
If it is said to be movement, it is not really existent, because as soon as it is born it perishes and has no meaning of movement.
Because dharmas in the process of arising do not require a cause for their cessation, and if cessation required a cause, it would not be cessation.
If it is said that there is a form that is neither revealing nor shaping, that is produced by mind, and that moves the arms, etc., it is called bodily intimation.
This is not reasonable, because if it is movement, it is refuted by the previous argument.
If it is a cause of movement, it must be the wind element, but wind has no indication and should not be called intimation.

Also, contact cannot be good or bad by nature, and it is not like visible form, smell, or taste. You should understand that the body faculty is like contact. Therefore bodily intimation definitely does not really exist.

However, there is a transformation of the consciousnesses of others caused by the mind, and the form of hands, etc., that is born, ceases, and continues in a series and moves to another place. It is like having movement and intimating the mind. Therefore it is conventionally called bodily intimation.

Vocal intimation is also not really the nature of sound, because a single moment of sound does not express anything, and a continuity of many moments is not real. We have already refuted external, resistant form.

However, because of the mind, there is a transformation of consciousness that is like sound, born, ceasing, and continuing in a series, and it is like having expression. It is conventionally called vocal intimation. There is no disagreement with reason.
Since intimation does not really exist, how can unmanifest action be real?
However, there is no disagreement with reason in establishing unmanifest action conventionally on the basis of the good or evil of volition and the limits of its activity.

That is, it is established on the basis of the state in which the seeds of good or evil volition that give rise to superior bodily or vocal action increase, or it is established on the basis of the volition that is the present activity of bodily or vocal evil that is suspended in samÄdhi. Therefore it is conventionally existent.
The World Honored One said in the scriptures that there are three kinds of action. How can you deny bodily and vocal action without contradicting the scriptures?
We do not deny that they exist, we only say that they are not material form.

Bodily volition that moves the body is called bodily action. Volition that emits speech is called vocal action. The two kinds of volition that are deliberative and determinative are associated with thought, and because they activate thought, they are called mental action.
Bodily and vocal volition that produces something is called action.

Because it is the path traversed by deliberative and determinative volition, and because it produces as its effect the retribution of suffering and happiness, it is also called a path. Therefore the first seven of the eight kinds of paths of action are also volition by nature.
Or, because bodily and vocal intimation is emitted by volition, it is figuratively called action.
Because it is the path traversed by volition, it is called a path of action.
Consequently, you should know that there really is no external material form, and that it is only internal consciousness that evolves resembling material form.
The dissociated forces also do not really exist.
Why is this?

Attainment and nonattainment, etc., are not like form, mind, and mental activities, whose substance and characteristics can be apprehended. They are not different from form, mind, and mental activities, whose functions can be apprehended. Consequently, we know that they definitely do not really exist but are established hypothetically on the basis of form, etc.
This samÄdhi is not different from form, mind, and mental activities in having a real substance and function, because it is admitted that it is included in the aggregates.
Or, because it is not included in mind, mental activities, form, or the unconditioned, like absolute nonexistence, it definitely does not really exist.
Or, because it is not included in other real dharmas, like other hypothetical dharmas, it does not have a real substance.
How do you know that attainment and nonattainment are different from form, mind, etc., and have a real substance and function?
Because it is said in the scriptures.
For example, it is said that a certain person possesses good and bad dharmas, and that the saint possesses ten unlearned dharmas.
It is also said that the ordinary person does not possess holy dharmas, and that the arhat does not possess the passions.
The words possess and do not possess indicate attainment and nonattainment.
The scriptures do not say that it has a real substance and function apart from form, mind, etc., so your proof is inconclusive.
The scriptures also say that a wheel-turning king possesses seven treasures. Does this mean that he possesses the bodies of others and insentient things?
If you say that he has mastery over the treasures and for that reason is said to possess them,
why not admit that the same is true of good and bad dharmas and not insist that he really acquires them?
If you say that the treasures are present and for that reason can be said to be possessed, how do you know that the good, etc., that are acquired are not present?
Because it is impossible for there to be real dharmas apart from the present, and because the present definitely has good seeds, etc.
Also, what is the superior function of acquisition?

If you say that it causes arising, then unconditioned dharmas would be produced, and all insentient things would never arise, and that which has not yet been acquired or has been lost would never arise.
If you say that the cause of arising is the acquisition that occurs simultaneously with the dharma, then the two kinds of arising that you accept would be useless.

Also, one who possesses good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas would have good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas appear simultaneously. If you say that acquisition requires other causes, then acquisition is useless.
If obtaining is the cause of nonloss, then sentient beings would possess it because of this.
The dharmas that can be possessed are not separate from sentient beings, and if separate from sentient beings, they cannot be apprehended as real. Therefore obtaining is useless in both cases.

Since there is no real obtaining, there is also no nonobtaining. However, in regard to the dharmas that sentient beings can possess, there are three kinds of possession hypothetically established in regard to states.
The first is possession as seed, the second is possession as mastery, and the third is possession as actual dharmas.
The opposite of these is given the name nonpossession.

Although there are many kinds of this nonpossession, it is only in the state in which the seeds of the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of insight in the three realms have not yet been eternally eliminated that nonpossession is hypothetically established and given the name of the nature of an ordinary person, because one has not yet achieved the holy dharmas.
How do we know that there is a real same species apart from form, mind, etc.?
Because it is taught in the scriptures.
A scripture says, There is a same species of gods, a same species of humans, and so on at length.
This scripture does not say that there is a real homogeneous character apart from form, mind, etc., so your proof is not established.
If you say that the real homogeneous character exists because the idea of sameness arises on the basis of that character, then grasses, trees, etc., should have a homogeneous character.
Also, when the idea of sameness arises with regard to the homogeneous character, the homogeneous character should in turn have a separate homogeneous character.
Since that is not so, how can this be so?

If you say that the real homogeneous character exists because the desire to act in the same way arises on the basis of that character, this is not reasonable, because the desire to act in the same way arises on the basis of the cause of habit from previous lives. Why must you grasp at the existence of a real homogeneous character apart from that?
However, on the basis of the similarity of the bodies and minds of sentient beings and the distinctions of their states, we establish the homogeneous character.
How do you know that there is a real life principle apart from form, mind, etc.?
Because it is explained in the scriptures.
A scripture says, Life, warmth, and consciousness, these three, should be understood as the life principle called life.
This scripture does not say that there is a real life principle apart from form, mind, etc., so your proof is not established.
Moreover, form has already been shown to be not separate from consciousness, and therefore life must not be separate from consciousness.
If life is a real entity separate from consciousness, it must be like feeling, etc., and not a real life faculty.
If this is so, how can the scriptures say that there are three?
The three are spoken of in a different sense, just as the four right efforts are.
If life is a real entity separate from consciousness, then life, heat, and consciousness will not exist in the state of unconscious samÄdhi.
Isnâ€™t it said in the scriptures that consciousness is not separated from the body?
If this is so, how can it be called a state of no mind?
We reply, that passage means that the evolving consciousnesses are not separated from the store consciousness, because the latter is the support of the former. We will discuss this at length later.

This consciousness is sufficient as the substance of the realms, destinies, and rebirth, because it is universal, constant, and is the retribution of karma. There is no need to insist that there is a real life faculty apart from consciousness.

However, the seeds that immediately give rise to this consciousness are distinguished by the power of karma, and the time of their duration is fixed. On the basis of this, we provisionally establish the life faculty.
How do we know that the two mindless samÄdhis and the life of non-percipient beings are real entities apart from form, mind, etc.?
If it does not really exist, it must be unable to prevent mind and its activities from appearing.

If, in a state devoid of mind, there is a separate real entity that is different from form, mind, etc., and that prevents mind from occurring, it must be called mindless samÄdhi. In the formless realm, there must be a separate real entity that is different from form and mind, etc., and that prevents form from occurring, and it must be called the samÄdhi of the formless realm.
Since this is not so, how can that be so?
Also, why must the prevention of mind be a real entity?
Like dikes and walls, a fiction can also prevent.

That is, when one cultivates samÄdhi, one is disgusted with gross, agitated mind and its activities, and one makes a superior vow to prevent mind and its activities. This causes mind and its activities to become gradually more subtle and more tenuous.

When mind is extremely subtle and tenuous, it perfumes the consciousness that is perfumable and forms the seeds of the most superior disgust with mind, etc. As a result of this, the seeds of mind, etc., are damaged and subdued, and gross, agitated mind, etc., temporarily does not appear. On the basis of this state, the two samÄdhis are conventionally established. These seeds are good, and therefore the samÄdhis are also called good.
Because the prior state of the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization seeks the fruition of nonconceptualization, the seeds perfumed thereby summon the consciousness that is its retributive result.
The samÄdhi of nonconceptualization is established by the nonoperation of coarse and active conceptualization, etc., and is provisionally established in the state of this samÄdhi.
It is established on the basis of the retributive result and is given the name of the result.
